intro: Acacia alpina, commonly known as the mountain acacia, is a shrub native to the high altitudes of southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, feathery leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces yellow flowers in globular clusters, which are an important nectar source for local pollinators. Acacia alpina thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to cold, arid environments. Its hardy nature makes it a resilient plant in alpine ecosystems.

This plant thrives in cool, moist environments with well-drained soils. It is often associated with rocky outcrops and open woodlands. Its distribution is limited to specific habitats within these two Australian states.

It is commonly used in reclamation projects due to its ability to thrive in harsh environmental conditions. The plant has been introduced to several countries in Africa, the Middle East, and parts of Australia.
